metadata.title: The Sun, Our Star
metadata.objective: Understand how the Sun powers life, how Earth's rotation and tilt shape days and seasons, and how to notice sunlight in daily life.

narration.voiceOver: Welcome. Today we’ll meet our star, the Sun. I’ll show you what appears on screen and walk with you through three quick choices. I’ll read first; you can decide when you’re ready.

show.text: The Sun’s energy warms Earth, powers weather, and fuels life through plants.

narration.voiceOver: Question one. What mainly powers life on Earth? I’ll read both, then you choose. Option A: energy from the Sun. Option B: light made by Earth itself. If you’re unsure, I’ll help connect the dots.

show.text: What mainly powers life on Earth?
Yes—plants capture sunlight, then pass energy through food webs.
Earth glows a bit in ways like heat, but life runs on sunlight captured by plants.

question.text: What mainly powers life on Earth?

teachingMoments.a: Exactly—sunlight captured by plants powers most life.
teachingMoments.b: Earth gives off heat, but sunlight is the main energy source for life.

narration.voiceOver: Question two. Why do shadows change through the day? Option A: the Sun goes around Earth. Option B: Earth spins, changing the Sun’s angle for us. Take a look, then choose.

show.text: Why do shadows change through the day?

extra.b: Earth spins, changing the Sun’s angle

show.text: Right—Earth’s rotation makes the Sun appear to move, changing shadow length and direction.
It looks like the Sun moves, but it’s mostly Earth’s spin that changes what we see.

question.text: Why do shadows change through the day?

choices.text: Earth spins, changing the Sun’s angle

teachingMoments.a: It seems that way—but Earth’s rotation explains shadow change.
teachingMoments.b: Exactly—rotation changes the sunlight angle we experience.

narration.voiceOver: Question three. Why do seasons differ? Option A: just because Earth gets closer or farther from the Sun. Option B: Earth’s tilt changes the angle and length of daylight. Pick the best match.

extra.b: Earth’s tilt changes sunlight angle and daylight length

show.text: Yes—tilt changes how direct sunlight is and how long days are.
Distance changes a little, but it’s the tilt that sets seasons by sunlight angle and day length.

choices.text: Earth’s tilt changes sunlight angle and daylight length

teachingMoments.a: Distance plays a minor role; tilt is the big reason.
teachingMoments.b: Exactly—tilt changes sunlight angle and day length.

narration.voiceOver: Your takeaway: the Sun’s steady energy shapes days, weather, and seasons—and powers your meals through plants. Notice sunlight today: one shadow, one warm spot, one plant reaching for light.

show.text: Notice sunlight today—how it shapes a shadow, warms a place, or feeds a plant.
